captions.text: Let's talk about education.
In most western countries school is compulsory, and state enforced.
Truancy can result in fines or even jail time for parents.
This isn't just a result of state coercion.
On a cultural level education holds a sacred status much like that of religion.
This is an institution that most never question, and that's a problem.
Did you ever wonder how it is that kids spend 13 years from kindergarten to high school
supposedly being prepared for life, yet when they get out they don't have any real skills.
Thirteen years and kids aren't taught how to grow a garden, how to build a house,
how to fix a car, how to balance a checkbook, or how to cook a healthy meal.
Thirteen years and kids come out without even rudimentary concepts of how to organize or lead groups of people,
without even a glimmer of understanding of how to resolve conflicts non-violently,
and we call this an education?
Yes we're taught how to read and write and perform some basic math,
but we aren't taught how to think for ourselves,
we aren't taught the principles of logic, or how to question an ideology.
What we are taught is how to sit in a desk and listen obediently
as the world is packaged into a neat little box that we are to accept without question.
We're taught to regurgitate that information for tests,
to give the answer that those in authority demand, but most of all we're conditioned to conform,
and the reward for faithfully jumping through all of these hoops for 13 years
is a worthless piece of paper that no employer even asks to see.
Kids exit high school barely qualified to flip burgers at McDonalds
and even for that they have to be trained.
Thirteen years is a long time. That's most of our childhood.
To have this much time taken by force with such pathetic results is unacceptable.
The problem here isn't a lack of funding,
the problem here isn't poorly trained teachers, lax regulations, or low quality curriculum.
the problem is our entire educational paradigm.
The system isn't designed to prepare children for the real world.
It's designed to format their minds and condition them for a life of subservience.
It's designed to create a population of individuals just smart enough to fill out paperwork and punch a time card,
but too stupid to question the system itself or the authority of those running it.
If we want to change course we cannot ignore this aspect of our enslavement.
There is no point laboring to wake up other adults in our lives if we send our children to be programmed by the state.
The revolution of the mind must include a revolution in education.
If this is a message you feel the public needs to hear then be sure to like, favorite and share this video
through many avenues as possible.
If you want more videos like this be sure to subscribe to this channel StormCloudsGathering on youtube
For updates and bonus content follow us on facebook facebook.com/Stormcloudsgathering

comments.author: anthony jett

comments.text:
This video criticises education, but offers no alternative. To those who 
agree with the message of this video, what sort of alternative would you 
suggest to education, and how do you explain the fact that education index 
and GDP per capita are so closely intertwined without admitting that higher 
levels of education DO offer more opportunities.

Anyone can criticise anything but then offering no alternatives doesnt 
really help at all. If there is a lack of real life skills then add some 
time in school for that, but dont diss the whole of the educational system 
for that.

As for the lack of morals taught in schools, I dont exactly see how it's 
the schools responsibility to do that. I mean if it WAS schools 
responsibility then who decides what morals to teach? Wouldnt that just be 
incredibly subject to different biases to whoever sets them?

I feel my school (in Gloucestershire, England) gave me a very good 
understanding of real life and I know that they'd support me if I needed to 
fill out something like a checkbook or finance for something I'd need, so I 
really do not know where this video is coming from.

Some last words, teaching how to build a house is definitely not job of 
school, but I agree that leadership SHOULD be taught, and in my school it 
is through many ways including sports, group work, having opportunity to be 
leaders in school etc.﻿

comments.author: Travis Hunter

comments.text:
I was a teacher during my working life, but not in the USA. I worked with 
kids with disabilities so I was not directly involved with the mainstream 
kids until later. What I did observe in our country was that the worst 
teachers climbed the ladder of power. They weren't happy in the classroom, 
they couldn't teach, so they got themselves out of the classroom by 
climbing the ladder.  Then, when they were at the top they could tell the 
good teachers how to teach and what to teach.  So, incompetence was 
rewarded.  I don't know if that occurs in your country, but I do get a bit 
worried when we get told that teachers are at fault.

What's at fault is the incompetent idiots at the top telling the competent 
teachers who choose to stay in the classroom and teach the kids, how and 
what to teach. They get ahead because they know the system, know the 
language of success in the system, and they use that.  They are so ignorant 
about teaching itself, that a great percentage of our children even leave 
school being unable to read and write. Why? Because the teacher is expected 
to teach everything and waste their time on absolute irrelevancies.

I agree the system has to change, but maybe we better take a closer look at 
what is actually happening.  I left the system as soon as I could because 
it got to the point where I had done my study time, got a good grounding in 
various different disciplines which I thought would be good to have and 
then went back out into the system, only to be told what to teach by those 
who had NO idea.

I went from being allowed to withdraw the kids from class and I ended up 
working in the classroom with the children supporting the class teacher. A 
glorified teacher aide. I don't mind doing that. What I minded was that so 
many kids with disabilities have underlying auditory and visual processing 
problems and frankly, the classroom is not the best place to "teach" them. 
They need rooms which don't have all the art hanging off the walls (visual 
distraction), where there is quiet (auditory processing problems) and those 
who do have hearing problems require to be looking at the person trying to 
teach them.  Sorry for the rant, but holy shit, the system is genuinely 
fucked.

Here we are taught how to build things, how to cook, how to program and so

philosophy is of course a mandatory subject aimed at providing the child 
with tools of logic, argumentation and metaphysical insight.﻿

comments.text:
+NemuriNekoChan In the US, it all depends on the specific school and 
district. Some public schools have all the classes you named, but its hard 
for him to generalize considering how large the United States is. For 
example: a general public high school in the district near me has from a 
standard algebra class to a college level Calculus II class and there's 
even a college level Physic: Mechanics & Electromagnetism class, but still 
the bare bones regular HS physics offered as well.

comments.text:
These are some of the most ignorant, lopsided, brainwashed asstastic 
comments I've seen in a long, long time. The problem with education is that 
we have multiple well-heeled corporate instigators manipulating facts and 
politicians. NCLB should mean No Corporation Left Behind. Common Core is a 
disaster and administrators drank the Kool Aid. Meanwhile, back in reality, 
all the teachers want to do is get kids to think critically and learn how 
to properly interact in a social setting, to use their resources and 
knowledge to engage and create on an age appropriate level.  Reading the 
posts here, nobody understands the stages of development or the value of 
learning widely. Someone posted that kids need to learn how to grow food, 
hunt, light fires...and while i dont disagree, these are not modern 
necessities for a global economic world power. Those can be taught by a 
family member. Another said he never learned his rights. Sorry, you were 
either sleeping or not doing your homework. Also, if you want to know the 
tiniest details of the rights afforded to you, then you need to spend about 
7-8 years in law school. True story.﻿

comments.text:
It's great to question compulsory schooling, but the problem is many people 
who search for alternatives will stumble upon something even worse, the

education teaches you how to be a mindless consumer drone that doesn't 
question state authority, then the Christian fundamentalist homeschooling 
movement teaches you how to be a theocratic fascist that believes anyone 
who doesn't believe every word of the Bible is inferior! The Christian 
fundamentalists have a monopoly on alternative education, so hopefully 
people will check out John Holt and not the plethora of "Christian" 
alternatives!﻿

comments.text:
Then they say, well there are electives you can take that teach these 
things. Well I say, how the hell are we to juggle all these "electives" 
with all the crap you force us to take and shove down our throats? I'm to 
busy trying to remember some theorem or some theory, then its some 
abstracted English class bullshit. All the teachers that teach actual 
useful stuff are looked down on by the required class teachers. But thanks 
to them I can build a house (Building Trades), lead people (Army JROTC), 
rip an engine apart(Autos). Then they put these stupid overly complicated 
names for these classes, like they're an embarrassment.﻿

comments.text:
How am I supposed to do that when my English teacher is a bitch and my 
English classis full of idiots that think its funny to do really dumb 
things. I don't get English either, its to abstract, to many 
inconsistency's, so many "rules" that are bent. To many it this kind of 
sentence, but if there is this one word then its this kind of sentence 
crap. I can get things that are put together, I can see it, or there is a 
set of rules that are never broken. I can get math because there are rules 
that are set and almost never ever change unless your around a black hole 
or something. The teacher gets really irritated when I ask a question 
because I don't get something. So how am I supposed to learn if I can't ask 
questions?

comments.text:
+Walter Strong
There are many ways in which a push of a button could end our way of life 
in this day and age. For instance, a button could be pushed to send a 
nuclear bomb to blow up in the troposphere over America, essentially 
creating an EMP that could wipe out the power grid. A button could be 
pushed to send a virus to alter the stock market algorithms, causing stocks 
to plummet in the blink of an eye, and panic would ensue.

We live in a world in which the economy is backed upon a fiat currency 
which is backed up by thin air and is mostly just made of typed up numbers 
on a computer screen.  We live in a world in which our species has the 
capability to wipe itself out of existance in a matter of seconds. 
Furthermore, we live in a country in which a small handful of people who 
own as much wealth as the poorest 350 million Americans combined are 
pulling all of the strings. We are not promised tomorrow, hell, we're not 
even promised the end of the night. Everything you know could be completely 
transformed or cease to exist in an instant. If you're not pissed off, 
you're not paying attention.
comments.author: Mike Rauch

comments.text:
